Award.AwardTitle: Casimir connections, Yangians and quantum loop algebras
Award.AbstractNarration:
Quantum groups were discovered in the mid--eighties as symmetries of 1 and 2-dimensional Statistical Mechanical models. After a period of intense development, they reemerged more recently as the symmetries of 4-dimensional supersymmetric quantum gauge theories, through the work of Nekrasov--Shatashvilii, and as the constraints governing the enumerative geometry of Nakajima quiver varieties, through the work of Maulik-Okounkov. The present proposal bears upon two such infinite-dimensional quantum groups which are associated to a complex semisimple Lie algebra: the Yangian and the quantum loop algebra. An important component of the proposal is joint between the PI and S. Gautam, and builds upon a precise link they recently discovered between these quantum groups. It endeavors on the one hand to promote the above link to an equivalence between categories of finite-dimensional representations and, on the other, to use this equivalence to compute the monodromy the trigonometric Casimir connection of the Yangian in terms of the quantum Weyl group operators of the quantum loop algebra, in a way reminiscent of the Kohno--Drinfeld theorem. The proposal has potential implications for the representation theory of Yangians and quantum loop algebras, quantum integrable systems and enumerative geometry.

Quantum groups are deformations of the most basic symmetries of Nature. They were discovered in the mid-eighties as symmetries of 1 and 2-dimensional statistical mechanical models and, amazingly, reemerged recently as the symmetries of 4-dimensional quantum gauge theories, as well as the constraints of a class of enumerative problems in geometry. The mathematical study of their intrinsic and extrinsic structures is often key in understanding, and solving, the physical and mathematical systems they govern, since the presence of these symmetries greatly constrains these systems. The goal of this project is to better understand the relationship between two such classes of infinite-dimensional quantum groups, and to use this relation to describe the evolution of the systems governed by the first as some of its physical parameters (masses for example) are tuned, in terms of the second.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Quantum groups are deformations of the most basic symmetries

of Nature. They were discovered in the mid-eighties as symmetries

of 1 and 2-dimensional statistical mechanical models describing

for example thin layers of ice. Amazingly, they reemerged recently

as the symmetries of 4-dimensional gauge theories, which describe

the interaction of elementary particles such as quarks, as well as

the constraints of a class of counting problems in geometry. The

mathematical study of these quantum groups is often key to 

solving the physical and mathematical systems they govern,

since the presence of symmetries greatly constrains these systems.

 

This project has resulted in two important advances in the

understanding of quantum groups.

 

The first is a joint discovery by the PI and his former student,

and NSF funded research assistant, Sachin Gautam. It settles

a 30 year old foundational problem in the mathematical

aspects of statistical mechanics. The solution relates, in

a very precise and conceptually elegant way, the symmetries

of the so-called XXX and XXZ models, which describe spin 1/2

particles such as electrons arranged on a line in an isotropic

background (XXX), or with some anisotropy (XXZ). These

symmetries, known as the Yangian and quantum loop

algebra, had long been suspected to be closely related 

since they behave in tantalizingly similar ways, but no

precise relation between them had been obtained prior

to this work. The work opens the door to the understanding

of a third class of quantum groups, the elliptic quantum

groups. These are in particular responsible for the symmetries

of the XYZ model (spin 1/2 particles in a completely anisotropic

background), and their structure has thus far remained more

elusive. The extension to elliptic quantum group is being

carried out by the PI and Sachin Gautam under a follow

up NSF grant.

 

The second advance, joint with the PI’s former graduate

student and NSF funded research assistant Andrea Appel,

is a key step in carrying out the PI’s long standing program

of understanding the multivaluedness of solutions of 

differential equations in the complex domain known as

the Casimir equations by means of quantum groups. One

of the goals of this program is to relate groups, which

describe the symmetries of macroscopic physical systems,

and quantum groups, which describe the symmetries of

microscopic ones. The advance obtained with Andrea

Appel is a crucial step in extending this link to arbitrary

Kac-Moody algebras which appear, for example, in string

theory. The completion of this program for such algebras

is the subject of ongoing work funded by a follow up

NSF grant by the PI and Andrea Appel.

 

This project has also involved the supervision of 

three graduate students: Andrea Appel (PhD 2013),

Yaping Yang (PhD 2014), and Gufang Zhao (PhD 2014),

all of whom are now visiting Assistant Professors in 

leading research US Universities. It has also led to

the organization of a week-long workshop for 35

graduate students and postdocs at UT Austin in

May 2014 on the subject of Yangians and quantum

loop algebras.
